why: First, this is a required. : ) Second, I love to planning and I recognized that getting data and using them in the right way can help me plan events that gain more pleasures from the participants. I took intro. class back in my undergraduate in Syracuse University and it was one of  my favorite classes I've took, cuz instead of reciting stuff, I really learned how to complete some real life task and have fun with the knowledge I just earned. I hope this intro class will give me a good idea on what is going on in the "datalized" world.
Lear more about programming language practices and projects in business strategy
I hope to understand the process of analyzing the data so as to create models that can predict future outcomes.  I can utilize these skills later on in my profession.

I've always been interested in how information can be extracted from large sets of data, and how the process can be automated with computers. Especially nowadays when data is everywhere and computer processing is scaling fast enough to deal with it. I'm hoping to finally learn practical applications to all of the statistics I've been learning, how to manipulate huge datasets, and how to extract information from them.  I'm also very interested in machine learning for classifying images or object/text recognition (not sure if that's part of this class, but I hope so!). PS - I actually don't prefer either fruit, but I'll have a sip of cider if offered...
Get some understanding of the concepts of Data science and get a direction to which areas I would be interested in Data science.

I am taking this class to learn the basics of data science and analytics along with understanding statistics and visualizations along the way. I aim to learn the foundations of data analytics which I can utilize in my future.
I am taking this class to know how data mining can be applied to real world problems

programming_languages: Python, Java, C/C++, Perl, R, Matlab/Octave
why: I am thinking about pursuing a part-time data science masters degree at NYU, and I hope to learn more practical data science techniques in this class.
To take one foot forward in my dream towards becoming a business analytic. I hope that at the end of the class, if given various data sets, I could analyze and get solutions on my own.

At work, I do a very particular brand of data science. It involves using a lot of regression and using a lot of in house tools to the point where I don't feel prepared to really do much outside of work. My ideal is to know things well enough to be able to help with any company's data problems using only tools that are easily available to me. Also, I'm generally interested in doing volunteer data analysis for non-profits. Finally, I LOVE learning.

I am interested in getting a more business-oriented perspective of data science and its applications in actual real-world problems. I would like to learn more about data analytics and how to communicate my data-related ideas in a more effective and engaging way. I am also interested in interacting and collaborating with other students in the class.
It's one of my prerequisite course, and most importantly I want to learn the business approach of data science.
I want to improve my communicating and presentation skills, plus grab some statistics knowledge.
I want to get a general overview of topics od relevance in data science. I want to attain first experience in handling big data.

It's the first data science class!   As an applied math major (focusing in Computational Probability & Statistics), I have a lot of data science bits and pieces.  I'm hoping this class gives me the stamp of confidence to go and use them, while caulking in all the gaps in my knowledge. I'd also really rather know ONE good method for accomplishing a task than a general framework for accomplishing MULTIPLE similar tasks.  What I mean by that is: I'd like to know how to use a single downloading & parsing package in Python well, rather than the theory behind downloading & parsing.  That way I can immediately go do stuff with them.

programming_languages: R, Visual basic (vba, vbscript-- have written thousands of lines of code), SQL (I'm an "accidental" dba for SQL Server 2008)
why: As a visual basic developer and DBA for a reporting server at Bloomingdale's, I write a lot of code. While I produce a lot of reporting and process automation, we do not currently use machine learning techniques as a basis for any decision making. In the future, I'd like to be able to implement statistical/machine learning techniques.

Since coming to Stern, I've become more and more interested in the business analytics opportunities in the curriculum.  I consider taking this course to be the next step in my progression towards the business analytics specialization; I also hope it will also give me some ideas about my trajectory post-Stern.

The main structure of Data Science applications. Understand the basics of Machine Learning and compute enough code to get experience. Go through many problems to realize how to solve them in efficient ways with computer science tools.

Because I want to learning something about the combination of data science and business work. I want to know how data science can be applied to business area, because people may know what the mechanism is but they may not know how to use them.
I am interested in knowing more about data science and applications of data mining.
I hope to understand the application of machine learning to business. (Most of my works involved building the tools and not using it, so this would definitely help)
It is my first class of Data Science, so I expect to learn basic concepts of Data science and Machine Learning. Also, I expect to build some basic projects of Data Science.
Because I will to know some basic knowledge about the data science and apply data science method to solve some real-life problems.

degree: NYU Polytechnic School of Engineering/MS in Management
why: I did my internship at TransUnion where I worked on Visual Analytics in Big-Data space. This caught my interest and hence I want to pursue my career in the field of Business Analytics and therefore I am taking this class.
To get a deeper understanding of business analytics and to improve my Python skills in a relevant way for what I hope to do upon graduation.
Data analysis has many benefits for engineering & business.  More practice in a learning environment to better skills.
This is a required course for data science program student. I want to learn how to apply the techniques of the data science field in the business world.

I am taking this class because I have become very interested in Machine Learning and its application to "real" -- and by that I mean vague, poorly-defined -- problems. I'd like to gain some experience choosing the right algorithms, the right approach; I'd like to gain some intuition as to what's practical and what's not. Essentially, I'm looking for Machine Learning "Wisdom", particularly in the Business Strategy realm.
First, it's one of the requirements of MSDS program. Also, I would like to know the relation between Data Science and industry.
